The Act may be cited as the "Human Rights Information Act". Congress finds that the national and international protection of human rights is a fundamental value, as enshrined in the Bill of Rights. Federal agencies possess documents on human rights violations abroad, which are crucial for foreign authorities to investigate and prosecute such violations. The United States will continue to assist foreign authorities in legal matters related to human rights. The United States will continue to assist foreign authorities in documenting and prosecuting gross human rights violations, including requests for declassification of documents. Requests have been received from Guatemala, Honduras, and a Spanish court magistrate regarding General Augusto Pinochet. The US follows procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders for declassification requests. The United States responds to declassification requests regarding General Augusto Pinochet by following procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders. Strengthening existing declassification procedures is crucial for protecting and promoting human rights nationally and internationally. Declassifying human rights documents in compliance with US security interests will enhance global human rights and accountability. The expedient declassification of human rights documents in compliance with US security interests will protect global human rights, strengthen accountability of Federal agencies, and save Government resources. The United States' commitment to promoting human rights and democracy globally has led to diplomatic, economic, and military efforts to end human rights violations abroad. The United States is committed to ending human rights violations abroad through diplomatic, economic, and military efforts. It is crucial for newly established democratic societies to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to prevent the cycle of impunity. The United States emphasizes the importance of newly established democratic societies fully investigating and prosecuting human rights violations to prevent impunity. This can be achieved through the establishment of truth commissions, human rights officers, or national investigations led by credible civil society sections. The US has a history of international leadership in ending impunity for gross human rights violations and promoting the rule of law globally. The United States has a history of international leadership in ending impunity for gross human rights violations and promoting the rule of law globally. It has ratified the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, obligating parties to assist in criminal proceedings related to torture. The United States, as a member State of the Organization of American States, should provide assistance in criminal proceedings related to torture and adopt measures for free access to information in cases of investigations for international crimes and human rights violations. The Guatemalan peace accords are also mentioned. The Guatemalan peace accords, supported by the United States, included an investigation by the Clarification Commission to uncover human rights violations and locate missing persons. Despite the investigation's conclusion, many questions remain unanswered. The Clarification Commission recommended utilizing all resources to clarify the whereabouts of the disappeared and deliver remains to relatives. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi was assassinated. President Clinton commented on the situation in Guatemala on March 10. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi was assassinated in Guatemala. President Clinton condemned support for military forces involved in repression and emphasized the need for peace and reconciliation in the country. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been advocating for human rights. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting documentation from the United States on human rights violations since 1993, which has been partially fulfilled but some aspects are still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by US Government agencies involved in foreign policy or intelligence. The curr_chunk discusses various government agencies involved in national security, including the Department of Defense, CIA, and National Security Council. It also defines "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" as per the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS REGARDING GUATEMALA AND HONDURAS. The Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records by agencies, specifically focusing on activities in Guatemala and Honduras after 1944. Agencies must identify, review, and organize these records for declassification within 120 days. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days. Grounds for postponement of public disclosure are outlined in section 5. An agency can delay public disclosure of a human rights record if it poses a serious threat to national security, outweighing the public interest, and reveals sensitive intelligence information. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it poses a threat to national security or reveals sensitive intelligence information. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it would impair national security, pose a risk to individuals providing confidential information, invade personal privacy substantially, or compromise confidentiality agreements. The postponement of disclosing a human rights record can be justified if it would invade personal privacy substantially or compromise confidentiality agreements that outweigh the public interest. It is not a valid reason to delay disclosure if an individual named in the record was an intelligence asset of the US Government. The disclosure of a human rights record can be postponed if the individual named in the record was an intelligence asset of the US Government, meeting specific criteria. SEC. 6. REQUEST FOR HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS FROM OFFICIAL ENTITIES IN OTHER COUNTRIES. When a US agency receives a request for human rights records from certain international entities or countries investigating human rights violations, they must review and disclose the records according to the standards in this Act. SEC. 7. REVIEW OF DECISIONS TO WITHHOLD RECORDS. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations to postpone public disclosure of human rights records. They direct disclosure unless there is clear evidence the record is not a human rights record or qualifies for postponement. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone disclosure of human rights records based on clear and convincing evidence. If postponement is approved, the Panel determines alternative forms of disclosure in consultation with the agency. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone disclosure of human rights records based on clear and convincing evidence. Upon completion of its review, the Panel notifies the agency head of the alternative forms of disclosure that should be made. These alternative forms include disclosing a reasonably segregable portion of the record, a substitute record, or a summary of the information. Upon completion of its review, the Appeals Panel notifies the agency head of the determination and publishes it in the Federal Register within 14 days. The Panel also notifies the President with a written justification for the determination, including an explanation of the standards applied. The Appeals Panel notifies the President of its determination with a written justification, including an explanation of the standards applied. The President has the authority to review any determination of the Appeals Panel based on set standards. The President has sole authority to review Appeals Panel determinations under the Act, based on set standards. Within 30 days, the President must provide a written certification of the decision, including reasons for postponing disclosure if applicable. The Appeals Panel will publish the President's determination. The President has the authority to review Appeals Panel determinations under the Act and must provide a written certification of the decision within 30 days. The Appeals Panel will publish any unclassified materials related to the postponement of disclosure of a human rights record. SEC. 8. REPORT REGARDING OTHER HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS.

The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on the declassification of human rights records for other countries after reviewing Guatemala and Honduras records. The report will be made public.

SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.

Nothing in this Act limits the right to request information from executive agencies or seek judicial review under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. Judicial review is also allowed under chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code.

SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. SEC. 10. Creation of 2 additional positions in the Appeals Panel for individuals with human rights expertise appointed by the President. Recommendations sought from human rights organizations.
